title: The Mighty Mighty Bosstones - Don't Know How to Party (1993)@fla

While â€œA Man Withoutâ€ and â€œIsaacharâ€ might indicate the labelâ€™s hope that the band would turn out to be more of a heavy metal actâ€”an easier product to market in the era of grungeâ€”Donâ€™t Know How to Party was proof that they wouldnâ€™t and couldnâ€™t be anything other than the Bosstones. 
While the group still favored firing-on-all-cylinders tunes like â€œOur Only Weapon,â€ â€œDonâ€™t Know How to Party,â€ and â€œAlmost Anything Goes,â€ they were moving away from the wild abandon of their early songsâ€”which often felt like a trip down a steep, unpaved highway in a childrenâ€™s wagonâ€”and toward structures that were more burly and heroic. A cover of Stiff Little Fingersâ€™ 1980 punk anthem â€œTin Soldiersâ€ sets the tone for the rest of the album. 
As the band started to write songs designed to get a club full of ruffians pumping their fists in unison, they also turned the world onto the patented brand of biting-yet-tuneful ska epitomized by â€œSomeday I Suppose.â€  (itunes.apple.com)
